overview_of_class: The course examines money, banking, and financial markets in the modern economy. It starts by looking at the structure of financial flows and intermediation in the economy as a whole, followed up by a more intensive look at fixed income and equity markets. It then moves to banking, covering banks' evolving structure and role, as well as the matching response of financial regulation. Finally, the course examines monetary theory and policy, including the function and history of money, modern central banking practice, transmission of monetary policy to economic outcomes, and new innovations in response to the recent crisis.
name: Money and Banking
title: WCAS ECON 308-0-20 Money and Banking

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 310-1 and 311 and Math 220, or comparable background.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two lectures a week, plus a possible TA section.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterms (20% each), a final (40%), and problem sets (20% total).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The text for this course is The Economics of Money, Banking, and Financial Markets, 11th ed. by Frederic S. Mishkin (ISBN: 978-0132770248). A variety of additional readings will be made available during the quarter. (Purchasing the 10th edition of Mishkin's text instead is fine.)
